title: MLB DFS Bargains: Wednesday 9
text:
Welcome to MLB DFS Bargains. We’ll split the analysis into three groups: very cheap, mid-tier, and expensive. A greater emphasis will be placed on the lower end of the price scale.

Please note, these player picks were organized early in the day. For MLB contests, always check lineups and weather closer to game time. Rain, wind, or unexpected managerial decisions could open up additional sources of value. Be sure to keep an eye on the MLB Headlines and Injuries desk.

Editor’s Note: Stay ahead of the competition from wire to wire with rankings, customizable projections, trade evaluator, exclusive columns and more in our Season Pass. And start using optimized lineups with our DFS Toolkit!

Scroll to continue with content Ad

Eight games are on the docket tonight.

DIRT CHEAP BARGAINS

Jakob Junis – SP – Kansas City Royals (vs Tigers)

The Tigers offense is terrible. This observation doesn’t qualify as revelation for anybody. However, they’re so bad that usually exploitable pitchers like Junis become tidy mid-tier plays. We can anticipate roughly a strikeout per inning over six frames with an elevated chance for a win bonus. He should receive plenty of run support opposite Edwin Jackson.

Gavin Lux – 2B – Los Angeles Dodgers (vs Antonio Senzatela)

After hitting eighth in his major league debut on Monday, the Dodgers threw Lux straight into the fire last night by batting him leadoff. The ultimate result was a bland 1-for-4 performance. Regardless of where he hits in the lineup, Lux is clearly a high value bargain capable of blowing away his tiny price tag. In this case, the difference between hitting first and eighth in the order will affect his popularity more than it affects expected outcomes. A matchup against Senzatela and a bad Rockies bullpen should help matters.

Mauricio Dubon – 2B/SS – San Francisco Giants (at Michael Wacha)

Dubon has consistently hit eighth in the lineup since joining the Giants, but his skill set belongs in the top of the lineup (specifically, this lineup). He puts plenty of hard-hit balls in play. He lacks for premium attributes like jaw dropping power, stingy plate discipline, or indefatigable contact rates, but the total package adds up to an average or slightly better play. Wacha tends to make short, volatile starts. There’s always a chance for a meltdown.

Josh Rojas – OF – Arizona Diamondbacks (vs Chris Paddack)

After a tepid start to his major league career, Rojas is on a bit of a hot streak. He’s back to hitting second for the DBacks although he’s still a good value if he bats sixth tonight. He’s a line drive and hard contact machine who skews towards fly ball contact. His bat is long through the zone which should help to fend off changeups from Paddack. It’s obviously not the juiciest matchup, and yet Rojas is probably the best value-play in the entire slate – at least until we see which unexpected players are starting.

Also Consider: Trevor Williams, Michael Wacha, Lewis Brinson, Willi Castro, Sheldon Neuse, Austin Dean, Chad Pinder

MID-TIER MUST PLAYS

Yasiel Puig –OF – Cleveland Indians (vs Ivan Nova)

Nova is on a heater. A closer examination of his performance reveals it to be a fragile hot streak. He’s still a highly exploitable pitcher to a quality opponent. Puig will likely bat cleanup despite an ongoing slump. His ownership rate will likely be low in deference to his recent struggles and Nova’s success. As such, Puig makes for an interesting contrarian play due to elevated home run potential and a valuable role. Teammate Franmil Reyes is a better bet for a home run. However, Puig projects to outperform him by a slim margin.

Also Consider: Chris Paddack, Paul Goldschmidt, Matt Chapman, Corey Seager

HIGH PRICED VALUES

Jorge Soler – OF – Kansas City Royals (vs Edwin Jackson)

With Khris Davis virtually irrelevant in DFS this season, Soler has filled his role as all-or-nothing multi-homer threat*. He’s on the cusp of reaching the 40-homer plateau. Jackson is an inaccurate pitcher who can hardly induce a whiff or limit hard contact. He’s coughed up 2.94 HR/9. Waiting behind Jackson is an equally terrible Tigers bullpen. This is a mouthwatering situation for Soler. He projects for one-third of a home run which honestly sounds pessimistic to me.

*Despite outlandish power, Soler has only one multi-homer game this season. Don’t let that dissuade you from hoping.

Also Consider: Shane Bieber, Hyun-Jin Ryu, Jorge Soler, Cody Bellinger, Mike Trout
